Caspian, with that pervasive air of mystery clouding him, transforms the passage, opening a doorway to Mosskarm, our gateway to the other side. The space we step into bears significant resemblance to our departure point but embellished with a grander tree and an overall tidier presence. A Caspian lookalike – Calahan – awaits us there, ready to reveal secrets etched into the walls at our questioning.
Their projections illustrate most of the Winter Court, with fiery spheres that burst, magma flowing, and two moons behind the Mosskarm peaks, one steadfast, one ever moving.
A myriad of plans sprout amidst us—gathering supplies, gathering whispers—while Corvaux advises caution, insisting on aliases to mask our true selves in this beguiling realm. And so the masks we don, adopting names not our own:

Aeren morphs into Kohatu.
Mirri transforms to Mirabelle.
Thaddeus cloaks himself as Ted Barney, with a third guise of Dath Lliuq secreted away.
Runa reverses her name to Anur.
And Corvaux reforges her name into Varus.
I offer the warmth of my amber orb that Vigil gifted me to Mirabelle, sharing the flickering warmth as I hoist her upon my back.
We seek snow outside, only to be met with humid air, a landscape of rock, sunflowers embracing a river of magma—an underground city chiselled into the heart of a volcano, where steam and heat power machinations foreign yet intriguing. It's a steampunk rendition of the home I recall, complete with a bustling populace weaving through steam-absorbing verdure.
Corvaux's touch upon a sunflower releases a yellow powder—sulfur, not the Pale Blight we feared. Apologies lodge in my throat as relief floods me; we are spared the encounter with that scourge.
Our steps lead us to an ink seller named Pride, who directs us to the other needs of our voyage: Crimson Inn, and a nearby hunter’s stall. Mirabelle secures me a luxurious cloak from the hunter for some coin, for which I utter thanks in Sylvan, much to their undisguised delight.
At Flaming Fortune, we might procure other trinkets of warmth, but likely not without draining our purses dry. Ted's act of learning Sylvan that ensues is nothing short of a marvel; Pride imbues him with knowledge of the language through some type of arcane … ritual? Either way: I find myself inspired by it, but, admittedly, a touch envious as well.
We head to Crimson Inn at last with Ted’s new knowledge in tow. A stabby knife contest of some sort ensues at a table behind ours. This inn promises an odd form of camaraderie, and I note the genasi across the way—a silent challenge flickers between us.
As Ted delves deeper into the contest, though, I cannot pass up the invitation to join ( to help further Ted's pursuit of finding out more about Zirel ). Mirrabelle and I both lending our hands to the knives. Such games may veil more than meets the eye, transactions of information resting behind every throw.
With Runa and Corvaux by our sides at the table, I can now only hope I won’t lose yet another finger.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 13
item.description:
Session 13 Days 22 - 23 of Bloomwave, year 515 T.A
Things got rowdy in the inn, as I let myself be roped into a chugging contest with Anur. I lost, spectacularly, ending up unconscious and carried off to bed. I came to with a jolt and a nosebleed thanks to Anur's efforts to wake me up, and we got into a bit of a half-hearted argument. Varus stuck by the entrance while Mirabelle and Ted stepped out. Didn’t really see much of them afterwards until this morning, actually.
Unforeseen sidenote: a bit out of the blue, Anur kissed me, somewhere between calling me short and calling me ugly. I'm not sure where that came from or what to think about it. Will need to think on that when I can get a quiet moment to myself again. Or not. Maybe I should just forget it, and maybe I will.
Following ... that, she insisted we talk to the halflings performing on stage. Varus came along ( or, rather, we just about begged her to, being the only one not completely preoccupied and sober, at that ). We bought the performers some drinks before getting into their story about bloody scenes in the snow and the destructive work of the poachers Anur's hunting. Somewhere along the way, we vowed to join them the next day as they head into the snow. We turned in for the night at length after that.
This morning, I found the scar on my hand is healing better than expected, with a new, opalescent stone-like quality emerging from the regenerated skin. My wounds have never quite healed like that, so whether I should be concerned by this or not remains to be seen …
Upon reconvening with the others, Ted informed me he obtained some new intel from Dex about an entity called Orionis, an archfey that landed themself in hell, possibly linked to his patron Zirel. The specifics of Ted’s intel are somewhat unclear to me – in fact, at this point, I’m only aware of half of what needs to be done by all my travelling companions –, but he allegedly needs to find the Free Sprites of Spring, quite a while away from here.
Mirabelle, meanwhile, seemed to have had a rough morning, looking outright distraught until she realized people were starting to wake up. She threw on a blanket and put on a happy front when greeting the rest of us. Seems like she's pushing through whatever's bothering her. ( Something to do with this Tlanbourn she’s chasing? )
As it stands now, we’re set to make sense of the day ahead. We're prepping to face what might come in the Feywilds, combating poachers, learning about ominous entities, and handling unexpected personal developments — all while maintaining the ruse that we’re a family of some unhinged type.
Note to self: Mirabelle and Varus are sisters in-law ( Varus married Mirabelle's late brother ). Anur and I are newlyweds, or was it recent divorcees? And Ted, well … apparently we just plucked him off the streets. I should probably circle back to this before we head out to make sure ...
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 14
item.description:
Session 14 Days 22 - 23? of Bloomweave?, year 515 T.A.?
We left the Crimson Inn and followed Trisandra, or Tris, as she led us out of Mosskarm using quieter paths. These were somewhat difficult to traverse, but they provided a beautiful view of the city. Outside, the sky was an indigo blue, lit by thousands of crystals that gave the impression of a night sky, along with an enormous moon that resembled the one from the Material Plane but was twice as large.
Approaching the exit, we encountered guards for the first time. They wore masks attached to their helmets and stood motionless, like statues, beside the giant doors that intermittently opened slightly to allow passage.
Finally, we stepped out into the cold. I braced myself against the blast of freezing air, a sensation I'd become somewhat familiar with during my time in Nordthorn. Tris set a brisk pace, leading us through the vast, pale landscape that made me feel small and brought to mind tales of the Water Plane’s icy expanses.
The journey took us three to four hours until we sought refuge inside a hollowed-out snow dome. Mirabelle shared the story of her tattoos—ink that appeared one day, making her easier to track — likely linked to her patron, I suspect, whom has been in her life for five decades, apparently.
Somehow, I let Mirabelle talk me into trying to woo Runa. She was not particularly impressed by my attempt and in hindsight, neither am I. Henceforth, I think I’ll leave the wooing up to others.
When we resumed our travel from the dome, Tris said we had another hour or two left and warned of a toll we'd have to pay when passing through lands scarred by war, where disturbing the dead was forbidden. In this region, crypts were well-maintained, and the dead were respected equally to the living. Winter here had a deep connection with death, welcoming the undead and honouring The Raven Queen.
Tris led us underground where, inside a cavern, she made a bloody offering to the red fungi – or redcaps, rather, stressing the importance of silence to avoid disturbing them. Mirabelle and I made our own offering, intent on not stirring any trouble unnecessarily.
We discovered a shrine illuminated by a massive statue with wings (Faen) and surrounded by nine tombs adorned with symbols of various gods. With some guidance from Ted and Tris, we learned that the tombs served as markers or memorials for those interred in the ice below.
Returning to the surface, we crossed a stream and found a massive hole in the ground (almost reminiscent of the one I found Varus in mere days ago …), beyond which lay remnants of a camp. Anur suggested setting a trap here and taking a rest while we waited for said trap to be sprung.
Tris, before taking her leave, handed Anur a feather from Puck's crest as an identifier to the Aiklings and departed on her own journey. Varus and Mirabelle took responsibility for the night watch, while the rest of us selected a covered spot to wait out the next few hours.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 16
item.description:
Session 16 Day 24? of Bloomweave, year 515 T.A.?
We wrapped things up in the gruesome aftermath of our scuffle with the poachers, with Thaddeus securing the magical pack the dwarven woman used to escape. Exiting the room, we then marched toward the dagger Anur is tracking. A split-second action unfolded in the main chamber: someone released a bolt from a crossbow towards Anur, narrowly missing her. The result? Another chaotic bout with poachers singling out Varus and Anur.
During all of that, it took but one spell for the very ground beneath me to soften, leaving a trail of lichen, moss, and fungus marking where I stood ( and stand, still ) — wild magic. The flora spreads the longer I linger in place. I suppose it is better than to be turned green or have my hair transformed into ivy, but I might change my mind about it if it turns out I'll need to hide from something sometime soon. This leaves little to the imagination as to my whereabouts ...
But I digress. The skirmish revealed the poachers' vulnerability to silver, much like fiends. Anur struck down the last one wielding a pair of unique daggers, one adamantine and the other enigmatic in its magic. I suppose one of those was the one she was tracking.
With Mirabelle's aid, I frisked the fallen, revealing crossbow bolts, a shortbow, a hand crossbow, and a curious pendant – gold coin pierced through its center, with a worn Asmodeus stamp on one side. Looting eventually netted us four platinum coins each, 2 of which I've since relinquished to Ted. Speaking of Ted: he, meanwhile, drew us into the cavern's main space, away from the heat of the lava, pointing out a plethora of flying beings, invisible save for his enchanted sight. He sketched their likenesses, the images doing little to ease my discomfort — pixies or nixies likely under hellish influence.
Our ensuing rest in the poachers' abandoned camp turned out pensive. Ted circled back to his musings on Asmodeus, which I conceded to the background of my perception as I sought solace in meditation. What catches my ear, though, are warnings: avoid pledging our souls, steer clear of dying on sigils, and don't imbibe blood from altars — lest we forget: souls are the currency of devils.
Varus reached a palpable breaking point that took me out of my effort to centre myself, rebuking Ted for entertaining infernal bargains. With fervour, they proclaimed the weight of souls and the gravity of making pacts with devils, not long after which they stormed away in exasperation, leaving the group ( and by Lady Sunnis, I hope that includes Ted ) to truly consider the potential ( or likely ) ramifications for oneself and the greater world.
A warlock-centred discussion then unfolded between Mirabelle and Ted, as it so often does, its intricacies eluding me as I descended back into meditation.
Alas, the brief respite shatters as Ted]]'s panic cuts through. His alarm crescendoed with Corvaux's shouting, a harbinger of imminent chaos spilling from the main chamber. Off to greet another potential demise we go.
Assuming we survive this, I hereby leave this note to my future self: check in with Anur, now that their hunt is ostensibly concluded.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 17
item.description:
Session 17 Day 24 of Bloomwave, year 515 T.A.?
We rushed into the chamber following Varus' alarm only to find nothing visible. I tried to investigate but got pulled back quickly by Varus. That's when I felt it—a familiar but unnerving resonance in the air, like when the spirits of the Circle of Seven would return. Yet this was a corruption of those sacred encounters, leaving a sense of violation in its wake.
Varus listened closely to the spirit, which repeatedly expressed a desire to be brought to 'my lady,' becoming increasingly agitated. I was intrigued, but sticking around did not seem like the right move, so we made our way topside once more.
Once above ground discussing our next move, Ted shared that a fiend had tried to grab Sid, before he quickly summoned them back. Varus was set on eliminating the fiend, but we realized that defeating it there would only be a temporary solution. What's worse, it seems that 'my lady' refers to Zariel, a prominent figure in the blood war, with other unnamed archdevils potentially fitting this descriptor.
Our debate on whether to rest at the Crimson Inn or march forward was shrouded by the risk of the devil following us, possibly targeting us as 'quality' souls. The threat of deals and the conniving nature of devils lingered in our thoughts.
I shared what knowledge I gained from my circle’s the worship of Dumathoin — how some souls have destinations after death, sorted by The Raven Queen before possibly being sent to places like the Styx if promised to a devil.
In the end, we chose not to risk any civilians’ safety by returning to the comfortable inn. Instead, we decided to hunt for Vestan Tlanbourn, hopefully aiding both Ted and Mirabelle's quests in that way. Our path seemed to be leading us towards the Autumn Court, though how to get there wasn't immediately clear. Anur and Varus suggested focusing on something specific about the area, like golden oak tree.
With concerted focus on golden oak and help from Varus, we navigated towards our elusive destination, passing through a mountainous landscape, eventually witnessing a clear sky filled with vibrant auroras, moons, stars, and even a constellation resembling a unicorn, subtly coming to life when unobserved.
Upon finding a cobblestone path by a stream, we stumbled upon a campsite and heard … arguing? Anur fearlessly went ahead to investigate and eventually led us to discover two sprites (pixies? nixies?). and a messenger bag with some items inside – including some expensive wine, apparently. The sprites advised us on who to watch out for and mentioned a village up the mountains ruled by Calisto.
Choosing to camp by the river, the weight of Ted's situation became more apparent — he feared that his use of magic was drawing him closer to death, and he did not hold back on emphasising that none of our attempts at offering a solution were insufficient to his mind. I admit that in some type of knee-jerk-like reflex, a part of me grew bitter at the thought of extending my help at all, but another part thought about my dealings with Da'yin Kuya and how deals can consist of a civil conversation and a balanced agreement, not a one-way ticket to demise.
Mirabelle proposed to commune with her patron for guidance, offering to prioritize finding Vestan due to their apparent dealings with Zirel. Meanwhile, despite some semblance of exasperation nestling within me, I planned to commune with Da'yin later in hopes of finding a workable lead to solve Ted’s plight.
Mirabelle and I first took the first watch for a frigid evening, however, readying ourselves for the long night ahead and the uncertainties that lay in wait. The fire has since gone out gone out and be rekindled. Now we wait for the hours to pass in temperatures not even my time in Nordthorn could have prepared me for.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 18
item.description:
[Session 18] Day 25 of Bloomwave, year 515 T.A.?
Overnight, I did as I promised: I sought out Da'yin Kuya for the first time since I left The Sevenfold Maze decades ago, and after my arguably messy entry and my adjustment to the immense strangeness of the whole affair, we had a lengthy conversation about what brought me to her to begin with. I spoke one of … Ted’s patron’s names and, shockingly, found my tongue wagging in tongues I don’t even speak – Abyssal, allegedly. Not even Da’yin was left unaffected by it.
The main takeaways: the source of Ted’s trouble is Obyrith, an eldritch race of demons, older than even most of the gods. Da'yin suggested we seek out one of the pools of Meilikki, the strongest deity in the Feywild, according to Da'yin ( makes sense ). If he is pure enough of heart, he should be accepted, and come out of it being his truest self.
Lastly, on a more personal note, she advised me to lie to some extent ( apparently, it's dangerous to be so honest ), and to be cautious with my words; even a lie, if told often enough, will become true when spoken in the Feywilds. I left with the promise to return when I have news and make more of a habit out of it. I will not wait another three decades to return, at least.
Upon coming to, I felt different — something in me had changed… My purpose has shifted, my horizons broadened. I am unsure of the implications, but somehow I seem to feel all the more strongly about what happened once I got out of my hut.
As the morning unfolds, Ted sits secluded, holding tightly onto a scroll and a knife, while Anur returns from a hunt, presenting a great deer to the camp — clearly successful in her pursuits of the wild game. I felt a bit dishevelled myself, ruminating on the night's encounter with Da'yin, searching for the right words to share with the group.
Ted before long revealed that overnight, he negotiated with a devil named Epiphany from the infernal realm of Malbolge, a prison realm of sorts. His deal allegedly involves gathering three remarkable souls for this devil, using a new ring as a tool. The deal should release him from Zirel's grasp. Mirabelle listens intently, cautioning him against following too closely in the wayward footsteps of Vestan Tlanbourn.
I, meanwhile, worry whether this demon will even have the power to undo a pact with something that is more than a mere demon as we know them, per Da'yin's explanation. Ted could not be swayed, however … I suppose all we can do ( now that Ted has left us ) is keep an ear to the ground to hear of any transgressions past the deal he agreed to — and simply hope he will find his precious souls in those who have earned such a … shitty ending.
ior. We bicker as usual, of course, but there's a shift in our rapport. Meanwhile, Mirabelle's concern extends to Varus, who's been wrestling with Ted's infernal dealings.
With Anur in the lead, we begin our climb up the icy cliffs. I spot a grey-furred tabaxi who seems to be everywhere, raising both curiosity and suspicion.
In a clearing, this tabaxi – Luck by name – greets us with puzzling mutterings and swirling pupils. He's concerned about his shadow and the disfavour of one Ambassador Ushan.
Pixies promptly arrive, and Garnet, mounted on a beetle, appears on my shoulder, demanding Luck's teeth or a special gift. I will admit: I was viscerally uncomfortable, and think I spent the majority of the ensuing time either sweating or shivering.
Gifts of narration and song were offered, and Anur even surprised us all with her skill on the lyre. With these gifts presented, the pixies departed — but I fear I'll have repercussions to deal with in return for my lack of preparation. I was told, in a whisper I wish to forget as fast as I can, to not "trip on my words next time", before they vanished. My anxiety swelled to the point where I openly sought the comfort of a held hand, wary beyond any measure I've ever felt before. Not even traversing the Sevenfold Mazework put me this far on edge.
Either way, with both Varus and Mirabelle kind enough to humour my request for someone to hold my ( admittedly sweaty, at this point ) hands, and Luck accompanying us, we climbed higher into the mountains, and settled in a cave for the night. Jade green hues shade our resting place, and in the far distance, a sunset hints beyond the jagged mountain tops. I can only hope I'll still be here come the next morning, rather than suspended upside-down by a tree, or comically disfigured by the displeased pixies.
If I was certain beyond any doubt that they can't read Terran, and that they can't access my diary, I would ‘compliment’ them and their ‘crafty’ ways. Note to self: never improvise a poem again. Also, next time think of something more dramatic. Good grief.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 19
item.description:
Day 25-26 of Bloomweave, year 515 T.A.?
In the presumed safety of our cave, we exchanged names, real and fake, amidst the tension lingering from prior events with the pixies. I felt uneasy, my nerves frazzled, a sensation that muted my voice more than I'd like to admit.
Jorinn, whom we'd come to know as Luck of the Draw, admitted once more he had lost count of his time in this place. Having been a merchant back in Sylvari, exile to the Feywilds seemed to have stretched long for him. Yet our conversation took turns; he even bested me at arm wrestling — which cost me five gold in the friendly wager.
Our dialogue ventured deeper — Jorinn's devotion to the Raven Queen lay in the medium of memories, a practice carrying more weight with each recounted past. Ambassador Ushan's mention brought speculation on the years that had folded since Jorinn had last walked among the Sylvari (300 at worst, apparently?!).
Arguably of more interest to myself, though, Jorinn is headed for the Silver Maple. He even confirmed his task as such must be to deal with the source of the Pale Blight, alongside various others sent out to what may well be certain death.
On first watch with Jorinn, the comfort of the comparatively temperate cold and a secure cave eased the watchful hours. The sky's nocturnal ballet showcased Lucanthus in its viridescence, a calming contrast to the previous night's capricious display. The occasional sound from outside drew our attention—a branch snapping, a tree falling—but nothing came of it.
Jorinn's tale of being ensnared by the pixies in their displeasure painted the forest as an unforgiving loop of traps and deceit. His warning of a potential curse prompted a check of my rations — indeed, I was down to one. In an act of providence, Jorinn went out to forage, and returned with an unexpected feast of bounty.
Dawn brought chaos as we clashed with the elusive dwarf that vanished into the pack during our encounter with the poachers. Her fate was bloodily sealed at the end of the skirmish. The issue of the pack persisted, though; Anur's desire to delve into it weighed against Mirabelle's insistence on understanding the hunter's narrative.
Anur's intent on entering the pack led to a collective decision; ensuring its security demanded creativity. The choice to pursue an animal guardian fell to Jorinn, who returned with an almiraj named Phlip, while I closed the entrance to the cave after patching up Anur (likewise alongside Jorinn).
We were prepared to enter whatever lay in the pack stealthily. Anur, in her guise as a fallen enemy, led us in — upon which all of us, save for Anur, were caged upon entering. Her quest for tokens to authorise our release sent her away, leaving us encased and uncertain.
The prison's bars were eerily reminiscent of the cold iron found in the Bitter Steppes at home, including their anti-magical properties. All we could do as such was wait in lieu of risking a botched attempt at escaping and triggering more alarms ( or worse ), until Anur returned with the means to unshackle us: tokens bearing Asmodeus' seal, striking deeper questions about our actual location.
My best guess to this point is that we're in a demi-plane of some sort. I suspected the Abyss for a moment, but the sigil anchoring the portal in place simply didn't seem to suggest it. All the same time, knowing the symbol on this seal has everything to do with Asmodeus, still raises questions. This place is called “Dain's Prison” – and by virtue of our last talk with Ted, I recall Glasya, Asmodeus’ daughter, rules the prison plane of the hells (Malbolge). What if this “Dain's Prison” is somehow connected to it? Related to it? It is the only way in which the symbols on these tokens make any sense to me.
Ah, I digress. We ventured further after a moment, down the stairs, and were greeted by braziers that seemed to conceal more prisons. Lining the walls, tables held both scholarly scrolls and unsettling dissection instruments. Amidst a cold emanating glow, Jorinn's and my attempt to obtain a shard from a peculiar crystal teetered between curiosity and caution—the material's fragility and volatility reminiscent of volatile cold iron.
The others already ventured farther down the stairs. Time to follow suit, rather than risk blowing up this place for the sake of a sliver of that cold, glowing crystal …
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 20
item.description:
Session 20 Day 26 of Bloomweave, Year 515 T.A.?
in which aeren decides to use everyone’s actual names again both because he himself gets confused + to confuse any strangers that might come across his diary, gods forbid
Luck and I gathered a hefty share of food from the larder before we joined the others, upon which I was tasked with creating an opening around the bars of some type of cell (these fools didn't account for a genasi!), granting Runa access to a figure huddled within — battered and weak, but our fighter-friend's approach radiated concern and tenderness. For a few moments there, I couldn't help but ponder the relationship between the two, and I was made to think of those whom I went my letters to before we set out for the Feywild.
The place prevented us from aiding the stranger, later introduced as Tanis, with magic, unfortunately, so we resolved to vacate the area post-haste to tend to her ailments properly. The goblin child that lingered in the corner, Jinx, agreed to join us in our retreat.
As we prepared to leave, our conversation turned to Spite, a tiefling mage apparently all to eager to live up to his name, had stoked in the tower. His 'floor' loomed with ill repute. The stranger tranger led us to a chamber that held a personal artifact – a cord with a pendant – that she swiftly reclaimed.
We swiftly left this demi-plane then and, once settled, Luck provided a potion for Tanis in a finely crafted goblet — special in some way, as he insisted it be returned to him after use. News of being in the Feywild startled her, but she swiftly mustered resolve, speaking of acquaintances in the Summer Court we might seek out. Tanis recounted her past — a captain who once stood sentinel against corruption at the Ironwood Citadel.
Tanis's tale unfolded as she wrapped herself in Runa's bedroll, managing her own care while Mirri divulged her pursuit of Vestan Tlanbourn in time — a name Tanis recognized with a scowl.
The discourse darkened further when hellfire weaponry and their devastating potential were brought forth by Mirri, who apparently found some in the unnamed demi-plane we just left (I still suspect it is somehow tied to Malbolge …). The weapons' power to sunder reality itself brought forth an inevitable discussion as to what next to do with the pack. We debated its fate, ultimately deciding to contain its threat within Corvaux's own enchanted bag for the time being. Despite the risk, Corvaux, took the decisive step, leaving us startled, but unscathed.
With preparations complete, we departed from our temporary cave haven, but not without another encounter with the whimsical pixies. To earn our passage, I recounted the story of my transformation, Da'yin Kuya's aid in helping me become who I was meant to be, and at what personal cost. Thankfully, the pixies seemed to accept my tale — at least I received no warning to essentially 'do better' next time.
Our passage paid by stories and teeth, we left the mountains with minds and hearts set upon the realm of Autumn. Our journey continues, the weight of our task and the newfound companionship of Tanis urging us forwards.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 24
item.description:
[Session 24] Day 28 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
Runa left overnight, and that took us all by surprise – though I get the impression I’m the only one that needs a moment to actually process it. She left behind only a note telling us not to follow and a poem, which seemed entirely unlike her, but, on the other hand, it just goes to show how little I knew about her.
In a way, it makes sense. She seemed annoyed by us more often than not, or at the very least aloof. I know for one I’m the one that gets attached far too easily — give me twenty-four hours at someone’s side, and if there’s no instant ill fit to speak of, I’ll wind up all too invested. She seemed the polar opposite. I would’ve liked to see what lay beyond that reserved nature of hers, but … well, that’ll just be another of those what-ifs, I suppose.
I didn’t have much time to process once I got up in the morning. It unveiled the first sunrise I've witnessed in far too many days. Seeing it at last, I felt a wave of something akin to relief.
Setting forth after spending some time occupied by Grout, Golden Oak was the direction we were to go in, though the road there was said to be home to a wailing witch, and was described as a necropolis of sorts. With Luck leading our path, an effort to choose the most direct route was constantly diverted by the wild's will. Maybe I’ll take charge next time …
Either way, at length we reached a temple of theRaven Queen by a cliff within a colourful, marshy part of the forest. I was taken by the beauty of the surroundings — trees adorned with colours that seemed painted by light. It was [Mirri]]'s keen eye that caught the the sound of a lone figure playing the lute, her chords striking an unnerving resonance.
Approaching the bard, later revealed to be named Deidre, she confessed to being trapped here and requested our help. It wasn’t too difficult to surmise, then, that this was the wailing witch we were warned of. Either way, she sketched a dire situation in vague details — jailers donning animal masks, leaving behind a fog over her memory.
Interestingly, she also read Corvaux's inked skin, identifying the markings as anchors of her roguish skills of sorts. She also seemed to grow anxious at Grout's presence. Afraid of canines ..?
Our resolve to help notwithstanding, we first entered a nearby temple dedicated to the Raven Queen, a place of memory and exchange revealed itself. While some offerings were made to the Raven Queen by those dedicated to her, I joined Mirri outside.
I gave her the moss I’d picked up some days ago ( writing this down so I don't wind up wondering where I left it! ), so she could exchange it for a Rowan stick on the ground. She explained it possessed magical protective qualities: it keeps internal magic in, and external magic out through a magical absorption sort of property. She intends to use the stick to work on something that might give her a bit of an edge — in the fight with Tlanbourn to come, I suppose?
As we set off towards our new objective ( the mansion Deidre is apparently tied to ), Corvaux soon sensed an ominous surveillance and before long, we found ourselves hidden atop a ridge, ready to thwart danger that loomed from the shadows.
The confrontation was sudden — a shadowy assailant attacking Corvaux. It began as a hidden strike but quickly escalated into open combat, with the entire group defending against the encroaching threat.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 25
item.description:
Day 28 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
After the battle, Corvaux and Deidre explored the fallen tree where it all began. The tree bristled with an unseen force, and though my companions were out of sight, Corvaux soon returned with filigree weapons from the entangled bodies within its roots. Luck surmised they were likely the possessions of guards. Meanwhile, Deidre had run off and scurried back; the distance from the manor seemed to wear on her. She implored us to assist her in breaking the curse anchoring her to the mansion soon.
On the journey back, my gaze fell upon the younger trees. I recognized where old trees had once stood, their absence marking decades passed. We reached the mansion built upon ancient roots, deciding to pause for understanding before entering the dark spellwork that bound Deidre.
We scoured the first floor to no avail and then ascended. The balcony greeted us with paint stains, investigated and tasted by Corvaux. An intricate door bore sinister red runes, while a stone sigil whisked me back in time to a memory with Bell, a pair of cultists, and summoning circles.
The broken sigil captured my attention; I dedicated an hour to unravel its secrets, imagining its origins and destinations. The others, meanwhile, ventured into the sigil-guarded room as a haunting and beautiful tone enveloped me—the song of a star, a melody Wisp had alluded to, unheard of in Autumn. Time to put that sending stone to work once I have a moment.
I followed inside at length, found myself … welcomed by a wink from Deidre, and then … I don't know just what came over me, but I followed her as she ventured into another room. I won't get into unnecessarily embarrassing details, but it turned out I followed her right to the threshold of her bedroom. Scratched out self-deprecation here!!!
We parted ways and I trekked upstairs. entering there a chamber enshrouded in webs, where Luck identified a simple cat amidst the gossamer threads. Now, I'm not afraid of spiders, but I'd like to be able to see them and not be caught off-guard by them. So, do I trust these webs? No, not quite.
Anyway, Mirri stood fixated on a sizable egg—a dragon's egg she was keen to pilfer for future profit. I wish she wouldn't, especially after hearing Luck break … whatever he broke in an adjacent room. Whether Deidre was bound here by force or not, this is her home, right? Why rob her when we promised her our help? I find it all a troubling … lack of respect. Perhaps I ought to speak up before the day is over. Who knows what mischief a short trance will allow Mirri to get up to well before I've awoken after a night's rest!
The nearby books narrated tales of dragons, and before us was a statue, a jade wyrmling at rest. As we flipped through the pages, we uncovered a gruesome story of 'The Furthest Branch,' slaughterers and traffickers of dragon parts traded as vile trophies—a revelation that left a foul taste in my mouth.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 26
item.description:
Day 28/29 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
In the quiet hours before we sought out our bedrolls, I reached out to Wisp with the sending stone, discussing the peculiar sound haunting my thoughts. Wisp confirmed it was related to the star she could hear, and, since the Crimson Gaze is departing in two days, asked if I could trace the sound to its source before then—two days! How am I to even do that? It lingers as an unsettling challenge even now—cross-planar communication holds a sliver of uncertainty, after all, and I don’t expect the Crimson Gaze to hang around in the Feywild after departing.
The next morning, I got to wondering whether something's wrong with Corvaux—not in the offensive sense, but she's been sleeping; dreaming, even, instead of going into a trance. I wonder to what end she's doing that, but I haven't the heart to pry.
Instead, I asked Mirri not to indulge further in theft while she pored through a massive tome, urging some respect toward Deidre's home. Yet as words faltered, I found Mirri unmoved—and, somewhat comically, the egg she pilfered missing from her possession. I got the impression she blamed me for it …
Oh, well. Maybe Grout or Ralph got their sticky little paws on it. In any case, Corvaux and I headed off to prepare tea for the group atop glowing coals, which is when we stumbled upon symbols amongst the wood—a death's-head moth and a rough diamond, the latter which was especially familiar to me as a symbol of Dounuma's (or Dumathoin, if you will). A conversation with Deidre about such ominous icons is due at some point, but we had more pressing matters to resolve, first.
Together, Corvaux and I sought Deidre, where I clumsily offered tea, only to witness it discarded with nonchalance—an embarrassing testament to our different tastes, I suppose. We apologised for Mirri's pilfering. In retrospect, I'm relieved she wasn't there to hear it. I fear she'd have struck us both upside the head with a well-aimed Eldritch Blast in retaliation for speaking on her behalf.
Before long, our ensemble convened to devise a plan. The vault beneath the manor most likely contained the heart of the curse. Deidre recounted a symbol to beware of—a symbol eerily familiar the several I've found in the Stonecutter's journal.
decided to reveal the contents of the journal to the group—not just one person; not just to Corvaux as I did before, but everyone. The depth of the Stonecutter's work startled both Mirri and me with its potency, detailing entities known for pilfering souls, evoking the name of the dreaded Orcus, and a record narrating an inquiry into the lineage and purpose of missing souls. The symbols somehow seemed to depict anchors of such souls, in a sense?
Mirri stressed the power described in just these few pages, warning that it must never fall into Tlanbourn's hands. In fact, she would sooner set the journal and myself on fire than let that happen. She would have to; my resolve to hang onto these wretched pages and follow them to my destination is stronger now than ever before. I'll not give this up willingly.
Based on these findings, though, I theorized the circular symbols Deidre sketched out might just be what's anchoring her here—her soul, specifically. Depending on the exact state of the symbol, we might need to destroy it, or dismantle it by tampering with the Weave that powers it. It'll be tricky nonetheless, I expect.
So we traversed to the basement, Ralph and Grout left above to avoid harm. We found the entry sealed, but with Corvaux's touch, the stone slid away, revealing the steps into depths gilded as solid gold. Below, statues and a white bowl before a lit effigy of Lord Aurelius (or Eristalon, as we've come to know the name) beckoned for an offering. Deidre's wooden wolf idol granted us passage.
In the next chamber, a grand harp stood amid silence, and we discovered a sigil requiring a key—the solution lay within a treasury that awoke armoured assailants as Corvaux and Mirri crossed its threshold. After a scuffle, we claimed the gold and gems inside, aquamarine crystals particularly catching my eye—a near sacred piece of my homeland.
Mirri's critique of my fascination with the gems sparked bitterness; I felt the chasm my earlier request might have given way to, widen. Nonetheless, we affirmed the spoils were not Deidre's to start with (so I assume they belonged to this Eristalon), and divided them fairly amongst all of us. In hindsight, I wonder what might become of us if he ever finds out what we took from his treasury …
With this chamber practically emptied, a secret chamber revealed itself, one that turned our stomachs with decay and one that encompassed something other than golden, shiny wealth—organs, daggers, and the lingering questions that now we must still answer.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Aerendyl 27
item.description:
Day 29 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
Today's explorations in the manor's depths proved both wondrous and unsettling. As I examined the crystals and amber adorning the central table, Deidre donned a thorny crown, much to Mirri's chagrin. Corvaux sensed hidden magic within it, piquing our curiosity. Another crown similarly held promise of some magic potency—something that would turn "if looks could kill" into reality, I believe?
I admittedly found myself somewhat distracted during the explanation, for amidst the gems on the centre table was a piece of amber, flawlessly cut, with a small acorn suspended inside, glowing with a golden aura. Corvaux handed it to me, and I was transported back to my journey to Rakāuvi, to a tale an old man spun about Silvanus.
Deep in a forest far to the south-west of Rakāuvi, lies a tree where Silvanus slumbers. When he stirs, roused by anger, the tree drops golden acorns imbued with the power to cheat death itself. A seed of resurrection, forever tied to his resting place. We agreed to safeguard this treasure, should dire need arise—even if death, indeed, is a natural part of life. I won't have us lightly use such an item as such.
My attention then turned to a tome sealed within a blue dome—the Dendritic Grimorium. Its pages no doubt held forbidden secrets of controlling plants and forging unnatural connections, echoing Thaddeus' interest in the murals about bringing stone to life; turning it sentient. When I queried Mirri about her own research, her curt dismissal left me bristling. Her apparent bitterness hung like a shroud I could not pierce.
As we paused near the coffins, an unseen force intervened. From my pack tumbled a glass eye, its gaze fixed unerringly upon me. Panic gripped my heart—it seems a hag named Sabina, spurned by Deidre, is now watching my every step. This must be those scratched out pixies’ doing. Oh, I do so treasure the variety of life—but I will be the first to admit there is no love lost between myself and them. Either way, I hastily buried the eye deep in my belongings, where it must have spent the past few days, praying it would bring no further misfortune to my companions until we have a moment to address the matter properly.
We had a task to complete first, after all. We returned to the locked door in the first chamber, which after some trial and error, Corvaux managed to unlock, permitting us to pass farther below ground. Here, we encountered a sprawling sigil scrawled in myriad tongues—Abyssal, Druidic, Sylvan. Mirri understood the grand majority of what was written there; I needed only pitch in to help her decipher the Druidic, which seemed … strangely off-beat.
Her sudden demand for privacy between herself and Deidre caught me off guard. Reluctantly, I followed Corvaux and Luck, my heart heavy with worry for Deidre and frustration at my own impotence.
Relief washed over me when they both returned, seemingly unharmed, with Deidre proclaiming her newfound freedom. But a new mission called—the remains of Kai, her ghostly friend, awaited recovery.
A small jaunt later, we found ourselves in what felt like catacombs of sorts—the walls set with bones, skeletons suspended from chains, and coffins smattered about an off-shoot of the main chamber. Urgency seized Corvaux as she plunged into the well at the centre before long … with the Stonecutter's journal in her pack. Without hesitation, I went after her alongside Mirri, Deidre, and Luck.
As we sank deeper, the sound Wisp foretold grew ever louder in my mind, its call unmistakable…
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Corvaux 25
item.description:
The following log is written in an old style of Elvish
Day: Unknown | Location: Feywild
Normally I wouldn't write things down, but I feel like I need to. First Thaddeus left, and now Runa. It's understandable. It's a shame that I wasn't able to ask her questions about her relationship to Yewdon before she left like I meant to. I wanted to ask if she knew anyone who went in, if maybe I knew anyone that she knew so I could give information on them. That's on me for being too slow, I suppose. I can only hope that we meet again in the future so I can ask, though I fear that her return to the Citadel, especially when she has the knowledge that I and the Blight have escaped Yewdon, is dangerous information that puts me at risk. And yet, that isn't what bothers me most. What bothers me most there is heavy scribbling over the next few lines, as Corvaux wrote down their feelings and promptly decided that it was too much
We moved on. On our way, we came across a shrine of the Raven Queen. An unexpected find, though Luck appeared to be happy about it. Hopefully he can get whatever guidance or answers he wants from those within, of which there were three. The place doesn't feel right to me, though I imagine the cause of that is the usual personal problem when it comes to places of worship.
We also met a strange individual at the shrine. Deidre, an elven individual who unsettled me with how... I'm not sure how to word it. It's certainly not familiarity, it can't be. Though she recognised my markings? And suggested that they may be connected to my "inherent stealthiness" as I am loathe to call it. I wish I had better words for whatever the fuck is wrong with me, no matter how beneficial it is. Regardless, Deidre needed help, and I am certainly not against releasing a woman who was trapped against her will.
Further on, we found a place that Luck had been directed to for an errand. But it felt wrong. It felt like home. And still I foolishly investigated the fallen tree despite my warnings. I knew it was foolish. Nothing good comes from that which reminds me of home.
Since when did the shadows become attackers in their own right? I'd better survive this. Fuck.

item.title: Deidre 25

item.title: Luck of the Draw 18
item.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
Day: No clue, I lost count and that mountain might've been a time loop.
# FREEDOM!
I have no clue how long I have been wandering the same gods forsaken parts of this forest and mountain. When I first appeared in Winter there was sun, and I tried to go through the Krumholtz Mountains in what felt like a couple months after that. Stopped counting a long time ago, but the sun isn't here anymore just the moon. I ran into a pair of fey, and I tried to pull my usual routine on them when they asked for a gift. I found a small painting of an elf, and it was the closest thing in my pack I thought worked as a gift. I don't even remember what I said, something about it belonging to a lord. The pixies said I could pass, but the pixies lied!! I was grabbed maybe a few hours later, left hanging upside down in a rope trap. They told me it was "too boring" and something about teeth??? I tried telling them I had a better gift but they would not hear my pleas and left me there.
Theres no other word for my experience except torture, I would be left in some manner of trap for sometimes days at a time. I had enough survival experience to find my own food and water, but when the trap would release almost all of the food or water would be sabotaged. Pebbles in all the mushrooms, every animal scared off, I would try and boil drinking water from the snow but if I ever looked away for even a moment it would be knocked over or have salt poured in. I've learned how to not blink for at least 10 minute intervals while the water boils despite the harsh and cold winds just so I could consistently get safe drinking water. When I would rest, the best I could expect is to wake with pine needles in my ears and nose, sometimes poison ivy or similar. Don't even get me started on the singing, even now I swear I can still hear it. After a while of this, or if I got too comfortable, I was put back into another trap so the cycle could start all over again.
But finally after only gods know how long, some travelers seeking to journey past Krumholtz Mountains appeared. I wasn't really paying attention at first, normally I am very perceptive but however long I have been in this cycle I've never spotted a single animal or other living thing besides those pixies and the plant life. I got used to not really needing to keep an ear out. When they got very close, and I finally noticed the sound of crunching snow barely a few feet from me, I jumped a little bit. I surely looked and sounded crazy, I might be just a little crazy. I mean what other kind of person has to keep an eye on their shadow?
At first I thought them some new trick, something to spice up the entertainment I was bringing the pixies. Or maybe the pixies were still angry with the threats I made and brought people to hurt me, the largest of the group certainly looked like they could. Never again am I threatening a fey I can't beat. But no, just travelers like I was who must now bring a gift so they can pass. Some fine gifts, stories, performances, these pixies had a particular interest in either teeth or disturbing events.
Had I known ages ago that is what made for a good gift to these pixies, I would've never been trapped on this mountain. Early into my banishment to Winter but after the moon replaced the sun I fought off an ogre and pulled its tooth out. I couldn't really say why I chose to do it, but I carved the word "moon" into the tooth. But, I do want to remember my hardships. In no shape or form does this punishment fit the crime and unless the coward died first, Ambassador Ushan hasn't seen the last of me. I gifted the tooth to the pixies, the quiet one was very quick to snatch it from me. Then, finally, I was free to leave this mountain.
I chose to follow those Travelers as they marched onward, they're headed to one of the other courts, following a vision in their minds of Golden Oak. While I have never left Winter, I figured I could surely at least aid them in the journey, after all I didn't learn nothing from my time in Winter. They accepted, thank the gods. We're resting in a cave now having just gotten a glimpse of the sun. I think I will stick with these people, at the very least until we've left the feywilds. I wonder how much time has actually passed? I wonder if I actually remember when in the hells I even got banished.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Luck of the Draw 19
item.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
Day: Anywhere between 100-300 years, apparently
My senses are slowly returning to me, though I'm still in a bit of a elated state finally free of that same repeating patch of wood and mountain. My second conversation in who knows how long went not as bad as it could have. I don't think I made a bad impression of myself anyway. Better than my first with this group, I'm sure to regain my charm in time.. if said charm still applies to this day and age?
Apparently, based solely on Mirri's memory of Ambassador Ushan, it could have been as long as 300 years since my banishment to Winter. My thoughts immediately go to my family in Baheera, even in the ideal scenario of roughly a 100 years its unlikely anyone I knew is still alive. I hope the Angel's Share is doing well regardless, if they're still in business I have at least a centuries worth of donations to catch up on. I must keep moving forward however, theres still every chance I die in the Feywilds and nothing occurring in Rakāuvi matters unless I can get there alive.
Following that I had an amusing arm wrestling contest with Mirri and Aeren, I hadn't expected to win really but it was nice levity. I also learned that I have some like-minded companions in this party, improves the odds I'll try and stick with them after we make it out of the Feywilds. Mirri especially, they seemed very excited to meet a fellow charlatan. Corvaux had a connection with the demon influence in Silver Maple, in the Autumn court. So we found rapport, or I hope we did, in my mission to deal with that demonic influence. Corvaux described a "Pale Blight" that I should take extreme caution in facing, though they also said trying would be foolish so I'm having trouble telling where I stand with them.
Further interesting me in sticking with this group, apparently they're interesting enough to have people attempting to assassinate them in the dead of "night". Runa, a very large and intimidating member of this party, was attacked by some devil worshipping poacher with a paralytic poison. They had apparently fought a group of these before meeting me, a shame I wasn't there for it it would have been quite the memory. The assassin was fought off quickly, I managed the killing blow but truly Runa was more than tough enough to have done that themselves.
Runa figured that the assassin appeared in camp thanks to a magic bag they took from them earlier. There was some brief discourse between Runa and the group, the rest trying to learn more about why Runa was after these poachers in the first place. Eventually though it was settled we would see where this bag leads, try and deal with whatever or whoever's on the other side. The cave was sealed by Aeren, and a number of spells cast in preparation, that were unfortunately wasted as all of us but a now magically disguised Runa were sent directly to magic dampening cells.
Runa, through I can only assume was clever deception, got past a little girl that was in the other room and recognized who Runa was disguised as. After writing our names into a book and giving us each tokens stamped with the symbol of Asmodeus, something that I picked up must've had prior meaning to this group in addition to the devil worshippers here, we were able to walk free of our cells and explore what a disembodied voice explained to us was "Dain's Prison" and a demiplane.
As a sign off, I'm trying to steal a cold stone/gem/whatever that these people were using as a part of their cooler. Apparently it might explode if I try and chip pieces off, dying in a freezer is probably near the bottom of my desired ways to kick the bucket so I'll just stick to stealing the food if I can't get the rock.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Luck of the Draw 23
item.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
Day: Roughly 309 years (no wonder my back aches I'm 335 years old)
Ive done some more traveling with this group, and I have only become further convinced I would like to continue traveling with this group as I work on rebuilding my reputation and legacy, not that I had much of either before. Our journey has taken us to the Scarlet City, finally beyond the Krumholtz Mountains and very near the Autumn border. To sort of catch us up on entries Ive missed, Corvaux had caught a disease of some kind interacting with a portal to the Abyss when they were still on the material, we have plans on journeying to Silver Maple and dealing with the pale blight, we went aboard the Crimson Gaze to party, fight, drink, and get our fortunes read, I ended up learning exactly how long Ive been away by talking with the crew. Beyond that, mostly shopping for silver, pale blight protection, and my brand new companion Ralph an absolutely beautiful moorbounder that doesn't like to stay still or move from my side.
The previous night, after our party on the Crimson Gaze, I had gotten my first talk with Crowley in quite some time. I haven't just yet explained Crowley to the party, I can't really think how to word that I have a red eyed crowlock visitor in my dreams that gives me information. Not without sounding a little crazy, though it's potentially nowhere near as alarming to this particular group as it would be for anyone else. Crowley in their typical slightly disjointed fashion informed me it was still very necessary to head to Silver Maple, two demon presences were still around, they also mentioned something about siblings that I assumed was not being literal and just referencing that others like myself were sent. Crowley also made it clear to bring silver, holy water, and plenty of food which we were able to find in spades while shopping in the Scarlet City. Well except the food, I may just gather or hunt it myself.
While shopping I met Josiah, a merchant within the city, who had on offer a periapt that could significantly protect Ralph from the Pale Blight. It was very expensive and after all the shopping I was all but broke, so instead I offered up ranger services and have received a list of items to collect for a discount on a future item purchase. Hopefully I can gather the gold and items to be able to afford that periapt for Ralph, his safety has quickly rose to the top of my priorities. To that end, Mirri has made a deal with me for the shards and powder of Flail Snail eggs she had, and I ventured north with Ralph and Corvaux to find some other items. We ended up discovering a cave leading to a Frost Salamander colony where using some rabbits I caught, a nearby tree, and rope, I had set up a simple snare trap to try and get some of the frost salamanders teeth without too taxing of a fight.
Im writing this section while we wait for a salamander to get stuck in the trap, will update after the fight.
Update: It immediately went wrong. First of all it was MASSIVE I knew some surface level knowledge but I certainly wasn't expecting an ice breathing lizard the size of two or three moorbounders put together. Ralph had to pull out of the fight almost immediately, I spent a considerable amount of time just trying to keep them standing and taking mostly missed shots on the salamander with my bow. Corvaux thankfully is an extremely capable fighter, they handled the fight almost single-handedly. In a moment of shock and terror Ralph went down from the salamanders frost breath but I was able to heal them with my slumbering dragon vessel. Basically the only reason we survived is because my trap managed to hold the entire time, though Corvaux might've somehow won regardless given how much damage they dealt.
In the end, we got out of it with three of the salamanders teeth, Corvaux didn't really get anything out of this fight though so I should figure out some way to repay them for the help, it wouldn't have been possible without them after all. I've also decided Ralph simply won't be aiding in future combats, I can train them as a hunting/scouting companion instead of a battle one so they never get that close to death again. Frankly I'm a bit ashamed of how little help I was on the martial front of that fight, I need to be so much stronger than I currently am. We're resting for the night in the city and I believe we're headed to Autumn next. Very excited to finally be out of Winter after so long.
Note to self: Absolutely NEVER sell that slumbering dragon vessel, Ralph would have died without it.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Luck of the Draw 24
item.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
Day: Not just yet, almost?
Upon waking we were greeted to Mirri explaining Runa has left, leaving a note behind that they have left to the Ironwood Citadel. Some of the others were a bit disheartened at this news but truly I barely knew them, I hope I didn't come off as too cold about the situation.
We're headed into Autumn to a place called the Fallen Halls, I took the opportunity to guide the party toward "Golden Oak" the last time I stepped foot in a court besides Winter I was still a merchant traveling the roads of Sylvari so my sense of paths and other more comfortable ways of traveling were at best minimal and more likely non-existent. Despite that we did all make our way forward, finding ourselves in front of a shrine to the Raven Queen.
There was also the sound of a lute playing a strange haunting song, the source of which was someone with Elvish features named Deidre. Initially I felt that she spoke like a liar, or like someone who wanted something, I haven't met many who would offer so many compliments and not have ulterior motives. Perhaps I was getting the wrong idea from them but despite how they acted they were still asking for our help, something I wasn't going to walk away from. Apparently a group of masked people had somehow bound her to the area, specifically a mansion around here. Where we found her was roughly as far as she could go. When I asked why the only reason she gave was that they wanted her talents as a bard.
I asked that I get a brief moment in the shrine before leaving to help Deidre. I wasn't actually expecting others to already be inside, other worshippers for the Raven Queen. Deidre had mentioned she would visit the shrine often as well, though I don't believe she is an actual devotee. I took the opportunity to speak with one of the three tending to the shrine, ensure that I was worshipping the Raven Queen properly and to learn how I might better serve them. I even wish to move forward as one of their clerics if I can.
After that brief discussion, I was informed of a worshipper who was meant to collect offerings near a fallen but still living tree that had not returned with those items. I agreed to retrieve those items, made my own offerings of items I collected in Winter to the shrine, then headed out to find those offerings and help Deidre.
We have approached the fallen tree, and Corvaux warned us of danger, Deidre vanished with invisibility and Corvaux is approaching the tree. I stand ready with my bow sensing that this will almost certainly break out into combat.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Mirri 0.5
item.description:
20th of Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
A friend in the Guild tipped me off—someone matching Vestan Tlanbourn's description was seen near Jasmine’s Cliff with three others. My friend tailed them until they disappeared into the woods. Note to self: I owe them a drink.
I set out immediately and ran into two others on the road to the Felderwisp Farm—a cleric and a warrior. They made horrendous noise, all heavy armor and chainmail, so I slipped off on my own to get a better vantage point. My two “companions” made their way into the farm cabin, taking on the two guards, and I seized my chance to slip upstairs and corner whoever was waiting up there. I Charmed him and finally, after all of these years, got some answers: he was communing with someone named Zirel in a place called the Fallen Halls of Eristalon.
The cleric, Halek, was looking for a girl, the daughter of the farmers who lived here, whose blood coated the walls of their home. The half-orc was against me killing the cultists outright, as if they deserved any sort of mercy. Regardless, I stripped them bare and pocketed their daggers to sell later. I may not have been allowed to slit their throats, but I could, at least, humiliate them. From there, we headed to the barn, where I found a tiefling and a strange elf in a cage. I cleaved the tiefling’s mind in two with Dissonant Whispers and we managed to free the caged man, Malachi.
He knew the bastard’s name! He said he had last seen him in the Straterra University inSandfall City on the Earth Plane. Finally! A lead!
In a shrine on the property, we found the child, Nettie. The half-orc, Runa, comforted the child with the scrappy Tressym kitten she’d found in the barn. Nettie is a brave child, but gods know she shouldn’t have to be. She should never have had to endure this. No one should. She will be safe in the city, at least, and the local clerics can seal the rift to the Abyss here. It was open to the 108th layer… add that to my research list for when I next find a library.
Halek and I spoke about what I had learned from the cultist and he offered to send myself and my new… friend, Runa, to an Archive, where we might find someone who can help, someone who knows how I can get to that university. Here’s hoping, at least.
[Below are two small sketches: one of the cage that Malachi (sic) was placed in, and the other of Runa's Tressym.]
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Mirri 11
item.description:
22nd of Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Oh, ye gods. I don’t even know where to begin.
So much has happened in a single day! I haven’t had this much excitement in one solitary day since I was banned from that little town. Runa and I arrived in the Archive that Halek spoke of and I got to work immediately. One of the workers? Sages? asked for research requests. I asked about him and tore through the information they have on him. He’s more notorious than I thought, but I didn’t really get a chance to dig into it deeper.
I met some weirdos.
Thaddeus is half-elf, blonde and pretty; a warlock like myself, though his Patron is the stuff of nightmares—Zirel, the name I heard at the farm. The Thousand-Eyed Deceiver. And he is, of course, involved. Alas that we are entwined, my verbose friend. I only hope you survive it.
Aerendyl is Genasi and he seemed to know Malachi. They have the same gemstone eyes, or one of them, at least. The other is amber with a dark sclera. He’s TALL. He also dug himself into a hole and sat there for a minute after I described Malachi, so there has to be more to that tale. I’ll pursue it later. He seems sweet, though.
Corvaux is only a little older than me, a Shadar-Kai elf and a rogue. She’s stunning and it seems we have… similar tastes in facial tattoos. I think we’ll have quite a bit of fun together. Hopefully. She was overly nervous about the Pale Blight. Wonder what that’s about?
But, gods, there really is too much to write here. I took notes for half-a-dozen pages and I still can’t condense it all down. The 108th layer of the Abyss, heading into the Feywild, the Fallen Halls of Eristalon, Cabiri & other names for the… I’m going to call this demon-shit TED.
He was looking for something called the Crown of the Faceless King about thirty years ago. That last wanted poster of him was dated to about that time.
I can’t stop thinking about it. Seeing his face again, even just on parchment. The eyes are still the same.
He looks older. I suppose I do as well.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Mirri 12
item.description:
Session 12 and 13
23rd of Bloomweave, (Maybe?) 515 of 3A.
Day 1 in the Feywilds
I’m in the Feywilds! The last time I thought about this place was when I was a girl, listening to stories Mama told me of the Ni’Tessine summer home in Melianmar, of visiting Eladrin and the long nights of dancing. But Melianmar is tied to the Summer Court, and I’m here in Winter.
Which means we should be careful. I’ve gone with the Sunstar alias, and my companions have all chosen one as well: Aerendyl is Kohatu, Corvaux is Varus, Thaddeus is Ted Barney, and Runa is Anur.
Corvaux had a bit of an… episode when we first arrived in Mosskarm, mistaking sulfur for the Pale Blight. Thaddeus has made quite the impression on the locals. I look forward to seeing which of us first pops our cherry, so to speak, with the Fae.
We shopped around for some supplies. I got a set of bone dice; might spend some time “fixing” them up. It might be best to keep my scams on the low for now. I’m awfully tricksy, but the Fae are better. Maybe I’ll learn something…
Below are two sketches: one of the bone dice, and one of the tiefling Pride, surrounded by butterlfies and hearts, saying: "Ooh, Teddy, gimme a kiss"

Speaking of learning something, we’ve set up in the Crimson Inn here in Mosskarm. While the genasi, half-elf, and I sat down to a game with a Pixie, Dex, Runa spoke with the innkeeper about the poachers they’re looking for. Whatever they said, it earned us a fine reward of booze. I sipped it, but some of my companions drank it down like they were dying of thirst. So much for caution.
Whatever disappointment I felt in the other two, I was deeply impressed by Thaddeus. He and I managed to convince Dex to part with some more information about Zirel and anyone associated with them.
We got the drunkards into a room to sleep it off, though both of them seem keen on fighting it off instead. Gods help Corvaux if fighting turns to… you know.
I took some time to case the inn. I know that Runa disapproves of my methods, so it’s better if I do this on my own, at least until I know the others a bit better. I found a group of Sun Elves & Eladrin. They called me “Vari”—they’re Summerlings, refugees. My group of weirdos are now conveniently refugees ourselves. I had to double-down on a lie, but I got a great deal of information. The Spring court is in turmoil, the land turned into a battlefield. I don’t know exactly what’s going on, but if there’s chaos, he’s likely hiding in it.
Good thing to know: Corvaux is quick to back up a lie. We’re in-laws for the duration of our time here—she’s the beloved sister to my dearly departed husband. I don’t know what made me say it. No, I do. I just can’t think about it now. It won’t change anything.
I thought of Paelias while in reverie. Of wiping his snotty nose when he cried after scraping up his knee, of putting him to bed while Mama and Rodan went out. I remembered… I remembered how it ended. It will never leave me.
Corvaux saw. Gods damn her back to wherever she came from. She saw. She was kind, sitting beside me and talking about it. She tried to comfort me, to tell me there is nothing to be ashamed of, gnawing on myself like an animal. She doesn’t understand. She cannot understand.
I’m the only one in my wretched bloodline to know shame. It’s the only thing that keeps me from turning out like There is a large splotch of ink here, where a pen was pressed to the point of breaking.
I am the harbinger of my own fate. I will not chew my nails.
I will not ache for this. I am the harbinger of my own fate. I will not chew my nails. I will not ache for this. I am the harbinger of my own fate. I will not chew my nails.
I will not ache for this. Not again.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Mirri 14
item.description:
Session 14
Hopefully still Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 2 in the Feywilds
We’ve left Mosskarm. I’m almost disappointed that we are leaving so soon, but the wilds beckon. And they are cold. The necklace Aerendyl gave me keeps me plenty warm—I’ve used the Shiftweave to give the impression of winter gear without actually needing it.
We traveled for a few hours, I assume, given that time works a bit strangely here. The landscape is entirely blanketed in snow… it’s beautiful, in a way I can’t quite describe, like… the antithesis of the Void. We stopped for a break & I asked Aerendyl about his homeland. I know he was present at the university in Sandfall City, so regardless of what I find here, I’d like to know more. I need to know more.
Thaddeus and I discussed our pacts & our souls. I wish I could help him, I wish I could tell him that this will get better, but I don’t know if it will. I don’t know. What is clear to me is just how… lucky I ended up. His pact and mine are so vastly different. My patron is perhaps the only true friend I have ever known and even that word, friend, is too small a word to encompass the truth of it. And the worst of it is that I cannot even begin to articulate how my pact came about because—
Ugh. I encouraged Aerendyl to do something foolish to take their eyes off of me. His attempts to… “woo” Runa were painful to witness, but they made for a fine distraction. I hope we can leave this place soon. I don’t like sticking to a story longer than a day or two.
We paused our hunt for Runa’s poachers to visit an icy shrine. Our guide fed some Redcaps with blood to keep them sated and I followed suit. I don’t have any plans on waking the dead. Thaddeus, on the other hand, gave a very impassioned speech about what he might learn of lost civilizations if he had the option to rouse the dead. He also wants an interview with a Redcap and a Revenant if he can find them.
Thaddeus is a gift wrapped in silver ribbons for someone like him.
That is what worries me the most.
We’ve found a big hole. Runa’s poachers are probably waiting at the bottom for the monster that has made its nest there. We’ve set up camp to wait for these poachers to return. I’m not sure what we’ll do with them—our taciturn half-orc companion hasn’t said much about what their goals are here… but I cannot fault them in that regard. You keep some things close to the chest for a reason.
Corvaux and I will swap out on watch. I’m first. I wish I could sleep. I want to talk to Hallow. I want the comfort of the Void.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Mirri 15
item.description:
? Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 3 in the Feywilds
We woke to one of the most beautiful things I’ve ever seen. The second moon, Lucanthus, was shining high in the sky and the snowfall was illuminated by a prismatic aurora from the moon… it was incredible. I could have stared at it for hours. I sometimes forget just how beautiful these places can be… how often have I become too focused on the hunting of him that I’ve missed the rest of the world around us? I wish I was a better artist so I could have captured it forever.
I have, however, captured the beautiful sculptures that greeted us, molded by the careful hand of Corvaux: behold, the Snow-friends! We need a name for our weird little gang…

We’ve learned that the beautiful effect of the second moon is a Wild Magic Surge. Great. My fellow warlock sprouted a pair of gossamer dragonfly wings! I tested an Eldritch Blast, but didn’t fully cast it, afraid of hitting something or someone out in the darkness.
I tried to cast Guidance as well, but it also failed. Great! I’m absolutely thrilled to be as useless as a Drow in a desert, as Calimar used to say.
Gods, stop thinking about Cal, you thrice-damned fool. Thaddeus and Sid have gone down the Hole. I don’t know how long we’ll have to wait.
Thaddeus and Sid have returned, I assume. We can hear the archaeologist’s voice, but we can’t see him. I’m assuming that his invisibility spell hasn’t worn off, yet another gift from Wild Magic. He says he tasted (???) some coagulated blood and described the layout of the Hole. We’re going in after Runa’s poachers. Runa still hasn’t given much in terms of answers, but I’m hardly one to judge in that regard.
And speaking of Runa! They cast some sort of spell and sprouted ANTLERS. We hadn’t gotten far into a long crevice before the poachers noticed us. It wasn’t a long fight, or particularly difficult—one dwarf got away, but we’ll be following shortly. Runa found 600 silver for each of us, 3,000 in total, and I’ve picked up some silver ink used with evocation spells, a decent pile of Blink Dog teeth and claws, and bark from a Dryad’s heart-tree which is the only salvageable part of this godsforsaken hole because I’VE GOT WINGS?? AND THE MAGIC FUCKED WITH MY HAIR!!
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Mirri 16
item.description:
Session 16, part 2 of 3
Still Day 3 in the Feywilds
Just when I thought the day was going well. We landed in a fight with the poachers that Runa’s been searching for. They had the benefits of invisibility, or something like it. I managed to hear them coming, at least, though the damage I did was minimal at best. At least I got some money out of it.
Corvaux got hurt. Badly. I’d hoped some playful flirting and a gift of platinum might… I don’t know what it would have helped. I don’t know at all. I need to be useful to these people… or at the very least entertaining. I can do entertaining. I can do fun.
While we were recovering, taking shelter in the camp we raided, our dear Thaddeus revealed that he has been courting the idea of deals with devils in the hopes that it might free them from the Pact. I didn’t really get a chance to process the insanity of it before Corvaux tore him a new one and stormed off.
I managed to convince my fellow warlock to be patient. I know he’s scared, I know he’s desperate. I’ve been there and I’ve suffered for it. But something they said… something about trading something to Zirel in return for their soul. I felt Hallow’s fear and distress at the very thought of the question.
I don’t like this. I don’t like it at all. We need to get somewhere safe, back to some sort of civilization. I need to sleep, properly sleep. There are things Hallow and I need to discuss. I know he has a hand in this, somehow, and if he doesn’t… he would at least know where to start looking.
That is not a thought I should ever entertain. It’s as insane as Thaddeus wanting Asmodeus to break his pact. And it’s certainly not a thought I can voice aloud, knowing what I know now. I saw Runa crush the skull of that Drow. I’ve heard Corvaux’s verbal assault. Aerendyl seemed to sit peacefully out of the way, but that doesn’t mean he isn’t capable of the same violence as the rest of us.
I doubt that they’d enjoy my secrets. I’m loath to admit it, but it’s not just shame keeping my tongue tied. It’s fear.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Mirri 17
item.description:
End of Day 3 in the Feywilds
We left the hole rather suddenly. It was for the absolute best, of course, considering the harrowing details given to the group by Corvaux and Thaddeus. After a tense discussion of what our next steps are, we have decided to head to Autumn, to the Fallen Halls. To him.
To say I feel sick to my stomach at the thought of it is an understatement. It’s one thing to see his likeness sketched, to see wanted posters that show me that he has grown older, thinner. It is another thing entirely to face him again. I want nothing more than to put him in the ground. I want nothing more than to understand, at long last, why he has done any of this in the first place.
We left the hole, its ghosts, & its devils behind, hopefully. Along the path, we encountered two pixies, one in hysterics over what ended up being a simple abandoned pack. The other was quite fascinated with my hair, much to my anguish. I can’t wait for it to be back to normal, to run a proper brush through it again. Damn wild magic.
As we decided to set up camp here on the mountainside and continue on to a nearby village in the morning (?) Thaddeus said he wished to talk.
I gathered what I’d need to clean up after I commune with Hallow first. I’m used to the aftermath, but my companions are not, so it’s best to be prepared ahead of time.
Surprisingly mild swearing in Abyssal is scrawled across the page
“Screenshot 2024-02-15 at 12.18.09 PM.jpeg.png” could not be found.
you bastard idiot pointed-ear little fucker
How can one so smart as Thaddeus be so fucking stupid?!?
I’m on my third cup of tea because that godsdamned bottle we found in the pack is too expensive to waste, but—How can he even CONSIDER calling upon a devil to break his Pact? As if a deal with a devil will somehow be better?? As if Zirel will not know, will not punish such a foolish action??
Any plea for patience, for one godsdamned night to let me ASK Hallow what they know fell on increasingly deaf ears. Gods, I could strangle him with his own shawl for it. And what if he does it? If Thaddeus does call on Asmodeus or any other archdevil of the Hells, what then? What other sacrifices will be demanded to rescue an academic from yet another bad Pact?
It’s How
He started as an academic, too.
item.dc:creator: RudyTwoSpoons

item.title: Mirri 18
item.description:
Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 4 in the Feywilds
Thaddeus has left us.
It sounds much too kind when I write it like that, but the truth of the matter is this: he chose. He chose his own survival. I will not hold that against him. No, it is the path he chose that I take issue with. Three souls in exchange for his own, three lives forever altered, ended maybe, to save his own skin. I have done some nasty things to keep myself alive and I’ve no qualms with killing… but I could not do that. I could not force another to endure what I have, save the man who put me here.
I will remember the bright-eyed academic who had the habit of reading everything aloud. I will remember the young man I knew so briefly. I will mourn that I could not save him.
